ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to speak, write and understand Spanish
I developed skills in Spanish speaking and knowledge of Latin American culture.

I entered this course with a very small knowledge of Spanish and I left not only with a beginning foundation in Spanish, but also a skill set on how to successfully study new languages. We learned many of the basics of a new language (greetings, weather, colors, grammar) in addition to an emphasis on cultural and historical aspects of Spanish and Spanish speaking countries.
You learn basic Spanish, including elementary speaking, writing, and reading. You also gain some cultural understanding of the Spanish-speaking world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class is very time intensive but well-taught
the smaller class size really promotes learning and participation
The course was intuitive to learn and had good options for getting help.
Fun class environment with teacher and other students

Strengths: Asynchronous Wednesdays! These helped a lot as they allowed me to identify areas where I needed review and allowed me to have more time to complete homework and daily assignments. Another strength was the way students were supported regardless of background and prior experience. There were many opportunities for small group and partner work which I found to be really helpful in practicing my Spanish.
Weaknesses: I fell behind on supersite which made me feel disjointed - sometimes the grading on supersite was also strange but I went to my professor for help and was caught up.

This course was easily one of the best language courses I have ever taken. I learned more Spanish in one semester than I did in one whole year of Korean at Yale. The course is very conducive to learning Spanish in the most efficient way. Meaning you grow more comfortable speaking, reading, and writing faster yet with minimal "busy" work.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want to learn a new language, Spanish is a great language to learn
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student who wants to learn Spanish.

Yes! I had taken Latin and only knew a handful of Spanish phrases before taking level 1. I felt supported in the course and learned from my peers and my professor. There were many ways the course sets you up for success especially with its emphasis on how to learn a language. This was affirmed in the variety of activities we did during class from partner speaking and conversations, small group projects, reading poems, listening to songs etc. Additionally although having work due every day can be difficult, it didn't feel enormous to incorporate into my daily schedule (my advice would be to plan to do the daily homework as soon as you can that day so you are not completing it at midnight).
Absolutely! Spanish is an incredibly useful language, and Yale's Spanish program is optimally organized to help students learn Spanish.
